channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Without F-16s, Ukraine’s Counteroffensive Is Missing a Key Piece
item.description: Most military experts doubt that they would have, and say that Kyiv can still prevail without them.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:description: Dutch Air Force F-16 fighter jets over the Netherlands in July. The Biden administration waited over a year before agreeing to have NATO countries send F-16s to Ukraine.

item.title: Deadly Boat Wreck in Senegal Caused by Patrols Chasing Migrants
item.description: Patrol vessels were pursuing a fishing boat loaded with migrants bound for Spain when it struck rocks off a beach in Senegal’s capital, locals say, leaving at least 16 people dead.
item.dc:creator: Dionne Searcey and Mady Camara
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:credit: Carmen Abd Ali for The New York Times
item.media:description: An open wooden fishing boat that struck rocks off a beach in Dakar, Senegal’s capital, was still partly submerged in the water four days later.

item.title: Italians Pay Tribute to Novelist and Activist Who Spoke Out Till the End
item.description: Michela Murgia was a voice for minorities and a lightning rod for political debate. She also garnered respect even from a prime minister whose policies she opposed.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Alessandro Vargiu/Mondadori Portfolio/Sipa USA, via Reuters
item.media:description: After announcing in May that she had cancer, Michela Murgia emphasized the importance of living life to the full.

item.title: Rome’s Umbrella Pines Are in Danger
item.description: While an invasive insect bears much of the blame for endangering a beloved symbol of Rome, critics are also pointing the finger at city government.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rome’s signature umbrella pine trees are as much of part of the city’s identity as its human-made landmarks.

item.title: Iran’s Ashura Rituals Have Become a New Form of Protest
item.description: Ashura, which mourns the killing of the Prophet Muhammad’s grandson and celebrates Shiite identity, has long symbolized the fight against oppression. This year, its chants have been turned against the government.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Arash Khamooshi
item.media:description: Last month in Tehran a group of men commemorated Ashura, Shiite Islam’s most sacred ritual, showcased annually with great fanfare.

item.title: Russian Strikes Kill 7 in Ukrainian Region Under Ceaseless Shelling
item.description: Ukrainian officials said two children and their parents were among the dead after the attacks on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian demining engineers last month in an abandoned village in the Kherson region, which has been subjected to relentless Russian bombardment.

item.title: Sex Segregation in Israel Grows, Raising Fears for Women’s Rights
item.description: Ultra-Orthodox members of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s far-right coalition want to expand the powers of all-male rabbinical courts, and to bar women and men from mixing in many public arenas.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: An ultra-Orthodox man walking past a sign in Bnei Brak, Israel, that urges men to not look at women in the street.

item.title: In Istanbul, Tombs of Religious Figures Still Draw Pilgrims
item.description: Turkey’s largest city is dotted with the tombs of religious figures, where pilgrims seek divine intervention. “When you ask for something from God, those who are beloved by God can be a go-between.”
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard, Gulsin Harman and Ivor Prickett
item.media:description: Visitors praying at the shrine of Telli Baba, or the Father of the Threads, in Istanbul.

item.title: Anwaar-ul-Haq Kakar Appointed Interim Prime Minister of Pakistan
item.description: The announcement comes amid growing speculation that elections — once expected to happen this fall — will be delayed until 2024.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood and Christina Goldbaum

item.title: Lai Ching-te of Taiwan’s Visit to U.S. Will Be Closely Watched
item.description: An outspoken critic of Beijing, Lai Ching-te aims to reassure voters and Washington that he will be a safe pair of hands if elected.
item.dc:creator: Amy Chang Chien and Chris Buckley
item.media:description: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party presidential candidate William Lai during the party congress in Taipei, Taiwan, in July.

item.title: China’s Military, ‘Chasing the Dream,’ Probes Taiwan’s Defenses
item.description: Day by day, the People’s Liberation Army is turning up the pressure, deploying an ever-wider array of planes and ships.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Chinese naval vessel near Dongju Island, Taiwan, in April. Beijing claims Taiwan as its territory, to be unified with force if necessary.

item.title: Fresh Fighting in Ethiopia Raises Fears of New War
item.description: Less than a year after the war in the country’s northern Tigray region ended, Ethiopia’s military is battling an ethnic militia in the neighboring Amhara region in a part of Africa already ravaged by conflict.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: Ethiopia’s prime minister, Abiy Ahmed, earlier this year. The recent clashes there follow monthslong tensions over Mr. Abiy’s proposal to dismantle special regional forces nationwide.

item.title: A Japanese Candy Tasted Like Nothing. Why Do People Miss It?
item.description: Flavorless (?) Candy, a convenience store product in Japan, spurred debate over what the “taste of nothingness” tastes like, if anything.
item.dc:creator: Hisako Ueno and Mike Ives

item.title: Saudi Arabia Appoints Envoy to Palestinians Amid Push for Ties With Israel
item.description: The Saudi foreign ministry said its ambassador to Jordan would jointly serve as an envoy to the Palestinians.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Arab neighborhoods in Israeli-occupied East Jerusalem. Saudi Arabia recognizes Palestinian statehood across the West Bank, Gaza and East Jerusalem.

item.title: Nechama Tec, Polish Holocaust Survivor and Scholar, Dies at 92
item.description: She wrote about heroic Jewish resisters in her book “Defiance,” which was later made into a film starring Daniel Craig and Liev Schreiber.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.media:description: Nechama Tec in 2018 at her home in Manhattan. A sociologist, she wrote about Jews as resisters of the Nazis and why certain people became rescuers

item.title: Climber Defends Finishing K2 Climb After Finding Dying Sherpa
item.description: One of the climbers, Kristin Harila, said she continued her summit of the mountain after finding a porter who fell from a cliff and later died.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron
item.media:description: Kristin Harila and her guide, Tenjin Sherpa, in Kathmandu, Nepal, this month.

item.title: Ukraine Makes Progress in Its Counteroffensive
item.description: Troops advanced several miles along two main lines of attack in Kyiv’s drive to reach the southern coast and sever Russian supply lines, while explosions echoed at the vital Kerch Strait Bridge.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers preparing an armored Humvee before heading to the southern front line.

item.title: A Withering Assessment of a Multibillion-Dollar Real Estate Windfall
item.description: Ontario’s auditor general found that the process to open up land in Toronto’s Greenbelt was influenced by and favored two developers.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Brett Gundlock for The New York Times
item.media:description: Doug Ford is not backing down from a plan to open some of Toronto’s Greenbelt to development.

item.title: Zelensky Called Him a Criminal. Now Ukraine Calls Him for Guns and Ammo.
item.description: In its hunt for weapons, Ukraine has rolled back anticorruption rules and turned to people once seen as relics of an anything-goes era.
item.dc:creator: Justin Scheck and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Serhiy Pashinsky in his office in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Wednesday.

item.title: Americans Held Prisoner in Iran Saw Promise of Better Relations
item.description: The five Americans who are part of a prisoner swap could be released by September under a complicated agreement with Tehran.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: Siamak Namazi in Berlin in 2015, the year he was detained by Iranian authorities.

item.title: Ukraine Fires Top Military Enlistment Officers After Bribery Scandal
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky said he was removing all 24 regional recruitment chiefs, as corrupt draft evasion schemes put the confidence of the public and Ukraine’s Western backers at risk.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Recruits take part in a drill during training at an undisclosed location in Ukraine’s eastern Donetsk region in July.

item.title: Biden Describes China as a Time Bomb Over Economic Problems
item.description: The sharply worded comments are the latest example of the president’s willingness to criticize China even as he tries to ease tensions.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: President Biden has signaled that he continues to view Beijing as America’s biggest economic competitor.

item.title: Tanker in Yemen Is Emptied of Oil, Averting Catastrophic Spill
item.description: More than a million barrels of oil on a tanker off the coast of Yemen were transferred to another ship bought by the United Nations. But now a new hurdle looms: Who owns the recovered oil?
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.media:description: An oil worker on the deck of the FSO Safer off the coast of Yemen last month. Crew members worked in soaring summer temperatures to transfer the oil to a newer ship.

item.title: When art and money meet
item.description: Encouragement, profit or exploitation?
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:credit: Nina Westervelt for The New York Times
item.media:description: Larry Gagosian at the Brant Foundation Art Study Center in Greenwich, Conn., last year.

item.title: U.K. Evacuates Asylum Seekers From Barge Over Bacteria in Water
item.description: Bacteria that can cause Legionnaires’ disease were found on the Bibby Stockholm, a barge that began housing migrants this week as part of a hard-line government policy.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: The barge Bibby Stockholm, moored on England’s south coast, took its first asylum seekers on board on Monday.

item.title: What Another Trump Presidency Could Mean for Australia
item.description: The author of a new book exploring that possibility says it would raise existential questions about the current alliance with America, with huge implications for Australia’s regional and global standing.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Donald Trump is the front-runner to be the Republican candidate in the 2024 presidential election.

item.title: Jacob Zuma Released From South Africa Prison After Brief Return
item.description: The authorities said Mr. Zuma, the former president, was a beneficiary of a new program to relieve crowding. His political opponents called the timing suspicious.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:credit: Jerome Delay/Pool/Agence France-Presse via Getty Images
item.media:description: Jacob Zuma, the former president of South Africa, in court last year. Mr. Zuma had served just two months of a 15-month sentence for defying a court order to testify before a national inquiry on corruption.

item.title: Ukrainians in Kupiansk Fear a Second Russian Occupation
item.description: The torture rooms in the battered Ukrainian city of Kupiansk have been empty for months. But Moscow’s advancing forces are just five miles away.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Emile Ducke
item.media:description: At the outset of the war, Kupiansk, only 25 miles from the Russian border, fell to Moscow’s forces before being retaken six months later during a lightning Ukrainian thrust in the Kharkiv region.

item.title: Russian Influencer Ksenia Sobchak on the War: Resistance Is Futile, So Find Ways to Cope
item.description: Ksenia Sobchak, one of the best known media figures still in Russia, says her fatalistic stance just reflects a grim reality. Some liberals call her a Kremlin stooge, while hawks see her as disloyal.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Maria Contreras Coll for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ksenia Sobchak, one of the best-known media figures still based in Russia, has called on Russians to just accept the war. She was interviewed while on vacation in Spain last month.

item.title: Debris From Downed Missile Fell on Kyiv Hospital Grounds, Ukraine Says
item.description: The Ukrainian Air Force said that three other missiles were aimed at military airfields in the western part of the country.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: Taking cover during an air-raid alert in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Friday.

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: The toll from wildfires in Hawaii.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: An area that was burned in Lahaina, Hawaii.

item.title: Prisoner Deal Could Smooth Effort to Contain Iran’s Nuclear Program
item.description: Iran and the United States appear to be observing an informal agreement under which Iran has limited its nuclear program and restrained proxy militias.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley, Ronen Bergman and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: Iran’s nuclear program has expanded in recent years to put Tehran within reach of nuclear weapons capability.

item.title: Ecuador Reels From Assassination of Fernando Villavicencio
item.description: The killing of Fernando Villavicencio marks a grim turning point for a once-tranquil country now awash in violence fueled by drug gangs.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz and José María León Cabrera
item.media:credit: Johanna Alarcón for The New York Times
item.media:description: A hearse with the body of the Ecuadorean presidential candidate Fernando Villavicencio leaving a morgue in Quito, the capital, on Thursday.

item.title: Russia Tries to Bolster Ruble as Inflation Adds to Economic Woes
item.description: The central bank in Moscow took steps to counter the currency’s slide, but the war and resulting sanctions have put intense pressure on the economy.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne
item.media:description: The Russian central bank in Moscow took measures Thursday to stabilize the falling ruble, amid economic trouble caused by the war against Ukraine.

item.title: What Happened to Britain’s ‘Crooked House’ Pub?
item.description: The beloved tilted landmark in the West Midlands area of England was razed after a fire that police suspect was arson, leaving locals looking for answers.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: The Crooked House in Himley, England, in 2021. The old building’s walls slouched sideways after coal mining under its foundations caused it to sink into the earth in the 19th century.

item.title: Biden Seeks $24 Billion More for Ukraine in Test of Bipartisan Support
item.description: The aid request is the first by the president since Republicans took over the House, and some party leaders have expressed opposition to spending more to help Ukraine beat back Russian forces.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker and Luke Broadwater
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers training in Ukraine’s eastern Donetsk region in July. American weapons have been critical to Ukraine’s success in resisting Russian forces.

item.title: Italy’s Government Takes Aim at Taxi Shortages
item.description: The government took steps this week to increase the supply of cabs after months of shortages, but critics say the problems with the industry run deeper.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Taxi lines at Termini train station in Rome. The shortage of cabs is “a disgrace to Italy,” the president of a consumer rights group said.

item.title: U.S. Reaches Deal With Iran to Free Americans for Jailed Iranians and Funds
item.description: Five American detainees will eventually be allowed to leave Iran in exchange for Tehran gaining access to $6 billion for humanitarian purposes and the United States freeing several jailed Iranians.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Desiree Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden has made bringing home detained Americans a priority.

item.title: Sweden Is Not Staying Neutral in Russia’s Information War
item.description: The country has empowered a government agency to openly combat online disinformation coming from foreign adversaries, and especially the Kremlin.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers
item.media:credit: Felix Odell for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sergels Torg public square in Stockholm. Russia has targeted Sweden with a concerted online campaign to discredit the country and undermine its bid to join NATO.

item.title: Russia Is Making Copies of Iranian Drones to Attack Ukraine
item.description: Called the Geran-2, the drones are a Russian-made version of the Shahed-136, which explodes on impact, researchers say.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.media:description: A Ukrainian police officer inspecting parts of what authorities consider to be an Iranian-made Shahed-136 at a site in Kharkiv, Ukraine.

item.title: Muon Discovery Moves Physicists One Step Closer to a Theoretical Showdown
item.description: The deviance of a tiny particle called the muon might prove that one of the most well-tested theories in physics is incomplete.
item.dc:creator: Katrina Miller
item.media:credit: Reidar Hahn/Fermilab, via US Department of Energy
item.media:description: The Muon g-2 ring at the Fermilab particle accelerator complex in Batavia, Ill.

item.title: Few Options on Niger Crisis for West African Leaders
item.description: The military junta told an American diplomat this week that they would kill Niger’s elected president, who they’re holding hostage, if other countries tried to intervene.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
Economic Community of West African States (Ecowas)
item.media:description: Amadou Adramane, second from right, one of the prominent figures in the military insurrection, was greeted by supporters at a stadium in Niamey, the capital of Niger, on Saturday.

item.title: Yandex Founder Calls Russia’s War In Ukraine ‘Barbaric’
item.description: Arkady Volozh is only the second sanctioned Russian businessman to take an unequivocal public position against the invasion.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: Arkady Volozh, co-founder of search engine Yandex in Moscow in 2019.

item.title: A Drone’s View Behind Russian Lines: Cratered Fields and Charred Armor
item.description: A Ukrainian unit sent a drone into Russian-occupied territory to surveil the battlefront, and it brought back vivid images of the Russian side of the war zone.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Diego Ibarra Sanchez
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sánchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A member of Doc´s UAV (Ukraine Volunteers Army) unit, launches a reconnaissance drone to monitor and gather information through the Russian position along the Southern Front in the Donetsk region of Ukraine on Monday

item.title: Israel’s Supreme Court Braces to Rule on Judicial Overhaul
item.description: The justices will be scrutinized as never before at a hearing in September on the first part of a judicial overhaul that the government pushed through Parliament, angering many Israelis.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Chief Justice Esther Hayut and fellow Israeli Supreme Court judges attend a hearing at the High Court in Jerusalem in January.

item.title: What to Know About Fernando Villavicencio, Who Was Assassinated in Ecuador
item.description: The presidential candidate who was assassinated on Wednesday had a long history in Ecuador’s public affairs, largely as an antagonist to those in power.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky
item.media:description: Fernando Villavicencio at a rally on Wednesday, the day he was killed.

item.title: 4 Nigerian Migrants Crossed the Atlantic on a Ship’s Rudder to Brazil
item.description: Four Nigerian stowaways hopped on a cargo ship not knowing where it was going, but hoping to find a place where they could claw out of poverty.
item.dc:creator: Julia Vargas Jones
item.media:description: Four Nigerian migrants on the rudder of a cargo vessel in the Brazilian port city of Vitória in a photo released by the Brazilian Federal Police. The stowaways boarded the ship in Lagos, Nigeria.

item.title: Six Colombians Arrested in Assassination of Ecuador Presidential Candidate
item.description: The candidate, Fernando Villavicencio, had been vocal about ties between the state and organized crime, in a country roiled by violence tied to drug trafficking.
item.dc:creator: José María León Cabrera, Julie Turkewitz and Genevieve Glatsky
item.media:description: A photo released on Thursday by the police in Ecuador shows six Colombian men arrested in connection with the assassination of the presidential candidate Fernando Villavicencio.

item.title: Typhoon Khanun Brings Heavy Rain to South Korea, Killing 1
item.description: After pummeling southern Japan again, the storm moved slowly up the Korean Peninsula, bringing torrential rain and winds. One person died in floodwaters.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: Rescue workers in Daegu, South Korea, checking houses for those needing help amid floodwaters caused by Typhoon Khanun on Thursday.

item.title: Rodriguez, Singer Whose Career Was Resurrected, Dies at 81
item.description: Two albums in the early 1970s went largely unnoticed in the United States, but not overseas. Then came the 2012 documentary “Searching for Sugar Man.”
item.dc:creator: Neil Genzlinger
item.media:description: The singer Rodriguez in 2012, the year he was the subject of the documentary “Searching for Sugar Man.”

item.title: Russia Downs 2 Drones Near Moscow, as Ukraine War’s New Phase Intensifies
item.description: It was the 12th time in the past three weeks that Russian officials had reported intercepting such aerial attacks in the heart of the capital.
item.dc:creator: Enjoli Liston, Valeriya Safronova and Paul Sonne
item.media:description: Military and police officials at the entrance of the Zagorsk Optical-Mechanical Plant, less than 50 miles from Moscow, after an explosion on Wednesday.

item.title: Russian Missile Hits Zaporizhzhia, Ukraine, Killing 3
item.description: Officials said nine people were injured, a church building and several local shops were destroyed, and the windows were blown out of several high-rise buildings.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The city of Zaporizhzhia was struck by a Russian missile on Wednesday evening, Ukrainian officials said.

item.title: Biden Orders Ban on New Investments in China’s Sensitive High-Tech Industries
item.description: The new limits, aimed at preventing American help to Beijing as it modernizes its military, escalate a conflict between the world’s two largest economies.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker and David E. Sanger
item.media:description: An order by President Biden will prohibit venture capital and private equity firms from pumping money into Chinese efforts to develop semiconductors and other microelectronics.

item.title: Was That an Earthquake in Rome? No, It Was a Travis Scott Concert.
item.description: The rap star’s show in Rome at the Circus Maximus, an archaeological site by day and concert venue by night, has raised concerns about the risks posed by crowds.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Francesco Lastrucci for The New York Times
item.media:description: A view of the Circus Maximus and Palatine Hill in Rome last year.

item.title: Amid Niger Coup, Nigeria Grapples with Potential Military Intervention
item.description: A coup in Niger could shape the future of a West African regional bloc and the presidency of Bola Ahmed Tinubu, the newly elected leader of Nigeria.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Ismail Alfa
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
Economic Community of West African States (Ecowas)
item.media:description: President Bola Ahmed Tinubu of Nigeria, center, at a gathering of the African Union in Nairobi, Kenya, last month.

item.title: Does Information Affect Our Beliefs?
item.description: New studies on social media’s influence tell a complicated story.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: Four recent academic papers found that algorithms used by Facebook wielded considerable influence over the spread of information but that did not significantly effect people’s underlying beliefs.

item.title: Poland to Deploy 2,000 Troops To Reinforce Belarus Border
item.description: The deployment comes as concerns are mounting in Poland, a NATO member, over the presence of mercenaries from Russia’s Wagner private military company in neighboring Belarus.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:description: A Polish guard patrolling along a fence at the Belarusian border in May. Poland, a NATO member, is adding 2,000 more military troops to the border.

item.title: 11 Killed in Vacation Home Fire in France
item.description: The victims were on an organized trip for people with mental disabilities in Wintzenheim, near the borders of Germany and Switzerland.
item.dc:creator: Juliette Guéron-Gabrielle and Claire Moses
item.media:description: Twenty-eight vacationers were staying at the holiday home in Wintzenheim, France, when it caught fire early Wednesday morning.

item.title: Imran Khan Appeals Prison Sentence in Pakistan
item.description: The former prime minister of Pakistan was jailed after being found guilty in a corruption case. The legal fight will determine his political future ahead of elections later this year.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum
item.media:description: Legal representatives for former Prime Minister Imran Khan of Pakistan at the High Court in the capital, Islamabad, on Wednesday. Mr. Khan was arrested and jailed on Sunday.

item.title: Dozens of Migrants Die After Boat Sinks in Strait of Sicily
item.description: Survivors said that 41 people, shunted by traffickers onto a small makeshift iron vessel, had drowned after it capsized en route from Tunisia to Italy.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: A pile of boats of the type often used by migrants in Sfax, Tunisia. Traffickers have increasingly crowded people onto such makeshift, poorly constructed vessels for the perilous sea crossing to Europe.

item.title: U.S. Nurse and Her Child Released by Kidnappers in Haiti
item.description: The abduction came as gang violence has begun cresting in Haiti and an international force may be headed to the Caribbean island nation to address the insecurity.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:description: Alix Dorsainvil, who was freed after her abduction. She is seen here with her husband, Sandro, who directs the aid group she worked with.
